name: Fast agricultural topsoil re‑formation after complete topsoil loss – Evidence from a unique historical field experiment

abstract: Erosion of fertile topsoil means severe land degradation and yield loss. Here, we show that reformation of the fertile topsoil and crop yield increase is possible by good agricultural management within a few decades. Evidence relies on a unique long‑term field experiment in NE Germany where the sandy Luvisol was excavated in 1964, topsoil removed or duplicated, and combined with different fertilisation regimes. After 26 years a new fertile topsoil had formed, attaining SOC and aggregate characteristics comparable to reference soils, corresponding to a sequestration of 28 Mg SOC ha⁻¹. The buried former topsoil lost 30–50 % of its SOC over five decades. The study demonstrates that contemporary agricultural tools can rapidly restore degraded arable land and contribute to climate‑change mitigation.

hasPart.name: V210 long‑term field experiment – soil chemical, physical and agronomic measurements (1964‑1991, 2015‑2019)
hasPart.description: Data from the historical V210 field experiment at the Centre for Agricultural Landscape Research (ZALF), Müncheberg, Germany. The experiment comprises three soil‑manipulation treatments (control, topsoil removal, topsoil duplication) each combined with three fertilisation regimes (no fertilisation, mineral NPK fertilisation, mineral + organic fertilisation). Measurements include soil organic carbon and total nitrogen concentrations, bulk density, SOC and N stocks, aggregate size distribution (macro‑aggregates >250 µm, micro‑aggregates <250 µm), density fractionation results (light, intermediate, heavy fractions), POM (particulate organic matter) stocks, crop yield records, and fertiliser application histories.

hasPart.acquisitionMethod: Soil coring, bulk density measurements, elemental analysis, wet sieving, density fractionation, aggregate size analysis, agronomic yield records, historical fertiliser application records
hasPart.experimentalMethod: Randomised complete block design with four field replicates per treatment; plots sized to match original V210 layout; sampling depth intervals 0–20 cm, 20–26 cm, 26–30 cm, 30–45 cm, 45–60 cm.
hasPart.researchObjective: To assess whether topsoil that has been completely removed can be re‑formed under conventional agricultural management, to quantify the rate and magnitude of soil organic carbon and nitrogen sequestration, to compare aggregate formation and SOC storage among topsoil removal, duplication and control treatments, and to evaluate the role of N fertilisation in restoring soil fertility and crop yields.
